XML Modeler and Strongly Typed XML

Lesson
objectives ¢ Describe key XML concepts— XML elements,

XSD, and Serialization

¢ Import and export strongly typed XML using
Gosu and an XSD

« Use XML models to extract data in XML
format

« Use XML Modeler to create XML models

XML Review

| XML: Review

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<config xmlns="http://guidewire.com/config">
<param name="CurrencyURL" value="">http://acme.x.com</param>
<database name="TADatabase" dbtype="h2" autoupgrade="true">
<param name="jdbcURL" value="jdbce:h2:file:ta/db/ta"/>
<param name="jdbcURLtest" value="jdbc:h2:file:ta/db/test"/>
<param name="stmtPool.enabled" value=" false"/>
</database>
<security sessiontimeoutsecs="10800"/>

</config>

Extensible Markup Language (XML) is a hierarchy
data structure designed to transport and store data

| XML elements

OI HUVsrwW

10

<param name="CurrencyURL" value="">http://acme.x.com</param>
<database name="TADatabase" dbtype="h2" autoupgrade="true">
<param name="jdbcURL" value="jdbc:h2:file:ta/db/ta"/>
<param name="jdbcURLtest" value="jdbc:h2:file:ta/db/test"/>
<param name="stmtPool.enabled" value=" false"/>
</database>

<security sessiontimeoutsecs="10800"/>

XML elements have:

« Acase sensitive name

* An opening and closing declaration

* One or more optional attribute name/value pairs

Contents can be Empty, have Text, and/or Child elements
¢ Line 3 is Text

¢ Line 4 is Children (5-7)

* Line 10 is Empty

element

| XSD (XML Schema Definition) G

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<xsd:schema xmlns:xsd="http: //www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" ... >
<xsd:element name="config" >
<xsd:complexType>
<xsd:choice minOccurs="1" maxOccurs="unbounded">
<xsd:element name="param"
minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
</xsd:choice>
</xsd:complexType>
</xsd:element>
<xsd:schema/>

An XSD (XML Schema Definition) describes

the structure for elements in one or more

XML documents

¢ Informs how an XML document can be structured ell
¢ Used to validate the structure of a document

| Serialization G

TOU 01010010 TN
11001001
——_—| ——_—

file.xml 01100100

file-clone.xml

¢ XML serialization converts XML elements into a sequence of bits to be later
deserialized

¢ Serialization logic can be complex for certain data types such as hexadecimal
values or images

| Untyped and strongly typed XML G
— Untyped = Strongly typed

If no XSD exists, then the parsed

If an existing XSD validates and
XML is untyped

informs the XML, then the parsed
XML is strongly typed

my cy
file.xsd file.xml

¢ [fan existing XSD validates and informs the XML, then the parsed XML is strongly
typed
* XML is validated against the XSD during import and export
* XSD must be known to Guidewire
* XSD parses the XML document

2121 W. Camden Drive Suite 17 Los Angeles CA

+ Use dot notation to reference the

+" " + addr.city

« An XML (GX) model generates dynamic XML based on an input object
¢ Accepts a single input object and can specify:
* XML-formatted values from that object
* XML-formatted values from related objects
¢ Use model anytime XML must be generated

+ Message payload, web service data, etc

| XML model base types

« Each model has a base type, which determines:
* The type of object you must pass to the model

* The data you can include in the model

* Properties ° Properties ° Properties
e Virtual e Seen as
e Database getProperty
backed method
e Related

entities

Alternate constructor can be used to:

* Incremental: export only those

properties that have changed

* Verbose: export properties, even

if their value is null

¢ SuppressExceptions: suppress

exceptions thrown during XML
construction

| Optimizing XML model output performance

* To achieve the best performance,

make sure you use an

XMLSerializationOptions object to turn

off sorting and validation

* Serialization is noticeably faster with

these options set

var payload = xml.asUTFString(sOpts)
print (payload)

| XML models labels

Labels enable an XML model's properties

to be filtered

+ When an instance of the model is created only a
subset of its properties are converted to XML

+ Different properties can be included based on context

Use case:

+ System A needs to include the key property and the

ABContact normal property called SysA

+ System B needs to include the key property and the four
BankAccount normal properties called SysB

+ With labels a single XML model can be used

Properties can be assigned multiple labels

Multiple systems use the same property

Gi

1. Select field
Key Property

<< Remove
Recategorize

Edit Labels

3. Add label(s)

OK Cancel

| XML model properties

¢ Every model has boolean properties
specific to XML models

* $ShouldSend: has at least one Normal
property in the model changed?

+ $HasExceptions: were any exceptions
thrown while generating the XML?

+ True, even if GXOption SuppressExceptions
is set to true

Note: The demonstration opens a new tab in your browser. When the demonstration ends, the
original course launch window appears. Return to this window to continue this presentation.

Question G

_— — |dentify if each statement about an XML model is True or False.

“ A)
B)
©)
D)

E)

Se Soe Se sees esse ese

It can take any number of input values.
It has a published XSD.
It can make use of conditional statements and for loops.

It can include values from both the object that triggered the message event and objects
related to the triggering object.

It can be used only for payload generation

Answer Gi

aa Identify if each statement about an XML model is True or False.

c A) Itcan take any number of input values. False — XML models always have a single input,
which is the object upon which to base the XML to be generated.

B) Ithasapublished XSD. True
C) Itcan make use of conditional statements and forloops. False

D)_ Itcan include values from both the object that triggered the message event and objects
related to the triggering object. True — XML models can do this by including fields from the
related objects in the XML model.

E) Itcan be used only for payload generation False — XML models can be used anywhere.

Soo eS oe ese Sse ese

format

Alternate constructor can be used to:

* Incremental: export only those

* Verbose: export properties, even

if their value is null

exceptions thrown during XML

| Optimizing XML model output performance

* To achieve the best performance,

make sure you use an

XMLSerializationOptions object to turn

off sorting and validation

* Serialization is noticeably faster with

these options set

| XML models labels

Labels enable an XML model's properties

to be filtered

+ When an instance of the model is created only a
subset of its properties are converted to XML

+ Different properties can be included based on context

Use case:

+ System A needs to include the key property and the

ABContact normal property called SysA

+ System B needs to include the key property and the four
BankAccount normal properties called SysB

+ With labels a single XML model can be used

Properties can be assigned multiple labels

Multiple systems use the same property

Gi

1. Select field
Key Property

<< Remove
Recategorize

Edit Labels

3. Add label(s)

OK Cancel

| XML model properties

¢ Every model has boolean properties
specific to XML models

* $ShouldSend: has at least one Normal
property in the model changed?

+ $HasExceptions: were any exceptions
thrown while generating the XML?

+ True, even if GXOption SuppressExceptions
is set to true

Question G

_— — |dentify if each statement about an XML model is True or False.

“ A)
B)
©)
D)

E)

Se Soe Se sees esse ese

It can take any number of input values.
It has a published XSD.
It can make use of conditional statements and for loops.

It can include values from both the object that triggered the message event and objects
related to the triggering object.

It can be used only for payload generation

Answer Gi

aa Identify if each statement about an XML model is True or False.

c A) Itcan take any number of input values. False — XML models always have a single input,
which is the object upon which to base the XML to be generated.

B) Ithasapublished XSD. True
C) Itcan make use of conditional statements and forloops. False

D)_ Itcan include values from both the object that triggered the message event and objects
related to the triggering object. True — XML models can do this by including fields from the
related objects in the XML model.

E) Itcan be used only for payload generation False — XML models can be used anywhere.

Soo eS oe ese Sse ese
